articles.headline: Maker Aware of 40% Failure in Hip Implant
articles.snippet: Documents from a California court case show that a Johnson & Johnson analysis estimated that a subsidiary’s hip implant would fail within five years in nearly 40 percent of patients.
articles.abstract: Documents from a California court case show that a Johnson & Johnson analysis estimated that a subsidiary’s hip implant would fail within five years in nearly 40 percent of patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: An internal analysis conducted by Johnson & Johnson in 2011 not long after it recalled a troubled hip implant estimated that the all-metal device would fail within five years in nearly 40 percent of patients who received it, newly disclosed court records show.

articles.headline: Google Still in a Struggle With Mobile
articles.snippet: While Google’s most lucrative business, search on desktop computers, is slowing, the search giant has not yet figured out how to make equivalent profits on mobile devices.
articles.abstract: While Google’s most lucrative business, search on desktop computers, is slowing, the search giant has not yet figured out how to make equivalent profits on mobile devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Although Google is scrambling to meet consumers as they flock to mobile devices, the question is whether it is moving fast enough.

articles.headline: A Tax Bite Tailored to Help All
articles.snippet: Everyone agrees that federal spending must be drastically cut. But there is an alternative: raising more money from all taxpayers, including the middle class.
articles.abstract: Everyone agrees that federal spending must be drastically cut. But there is an alternative: raising more money from all taxpayers, including the middle class.
articles.lead_paragraph: What would happen if the government raised everybody’s taxes?

articles.headline: Microsoft May Back Dell Buyout
articles.snippet: An investment by Microsoft — if it comes to pass — could be enough to push a leveraged buyout of the struggling computer maker over the goal line.
articles.abstract: An investment by Microsoft — if it comes to pass — could be enough to push a leveraged buyout of the struggling computer maker over the goal line.
articles.lead_paragraph: The effort to take Dell private has gained a prominent, if unusual, backer: Microsoft.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: For Rape Victims in India, Police Are Often Part of the Problem
articles.snippet: In many rape cases, the police spend more time seeking reconciliation, even marriage, between the attacker and the victim, instead of an investigation.
articles.abstract: In many rape cases, the police spend more time seeking reconciliation, even marriage, between the attacker and the victim, instead of an investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Not long after telling the police that she had been raped, a woman from South Delhi looked out her apartment window and saw the man who had attacked her laughing with an officer who had given him a ride back from the police station.

articles.headline: Country Returns to City Radio: After 17 Years, a Home in New York
articles.snippet: Nash FM, at 94.7 FM, will fill a conspicuous gap in the city’s media market and serve as a flagship for a multimedia engine that will promote the “country lifestyle.”
articles.abstract: Nash FM, at 94.7 FM, will fill a conspicuous gap in the city’s media market and serve as a flagship for a multimedia engine that will promote the “country lifestyle.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Country music is all over television, on dramas like “Nashville” and talent competitions like “American Idol.” Country stars are among the most consistent moneymakers in the concert industry. The genre’s growing sales are among the few bright lights of the music industry.

articles.headline: Algerian Attack Puts Focus on Worker Security
articles.snippet: Analysts say the attack could lead some energy companies to change how they protect compounds in the region.
articles.abstract: Analysts say the attack could lead some energy companies to change how they protect compounds in the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The gas complex in Algeria that came under attack last week, like scores of oil and gas fields around the globe, had been a world apart from the country that surrounded it, an oasis of relative luxury in a nation emerging from poverty.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: Obama Speech Leaves G.O.P. Stark Choices
articles.snippet: As President Obama’s second term begins, Republican leaders appear ready to accede at least in the short term on some matters, like increasing the debt limit.
articles.abstract: As President Obama’s second term begins, Republican leaders appear ready to accede at least in the short term on some matters, like increasing the debt limit.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s aggressive Inaugural Address on Monday presented Congressional Republicans with a stark choice over the next two years: accommodate the president’s agenda on immigration, guns, energy and social programs and hope to take the liberal edge off issues dictated by the White House, or dig in as the last bulwark against a re-elected Democratic president and accept the political risks of that hard-line stance.

articles.headline: Europe Is Edgy as Cameron Seeks to Loosen Ties
articles.snippet: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain has added to Europe’s malaise, vowing to reduce entanglement with the European Union or allow people to decide whether to leave the bloc.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain has added to Europe’s malaise, vowing to reduce entanglement with the European Union or allow people to decide whether to leave the bloc.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The French are engaged in a lonely military adventure in Africa. The Germans are preoccupied with domestic elections rather than regional affairs. Unemployment in some countries is at historic highs and economies across Europe are still mired in recession.

articles.headline: Boeing’s Battery Problems Cast Doubt on Appraisal of New Technologies
articles.snippet: The 787’s difficulties have raised questions about how regulators certify new technology and how they balance advances in design and engineering with safety.
articles.abstract: The 787’s difficulties have raised questions about how regulators certify new technology and how they balance advances in design and engineering with safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: In December 2006, the Federal Aviation Administration allowed Airbus, the European plane maker, to use 14-ounce lithium-ion batteries to provide standby power for the emergency lighting system of its new A380 jumbo jet.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Christopher Drew

articles.headline: Share of the Work Force in a Union Falls to a 97-Year Low, 11.3%
articles.snippet: The Bureau of Labor Statistics said the percentage of American workers in labor unions fell to 11.3 percent last year, the lowest since 11.2 percent in 1916.
articles.abstract: The Bureau of Labor Statistics said the percentage of American workers in labor unions fell to 11.3 percent last year, the lowest since 11.2 percent in 1916.
articles.lead_paragraph: The long decline in the number of American workers belonging to labor unions accelerated sharply last year, according to data reported on Wednesday, sending the unionization rate to its lowest level in close to a century.
